page.title: 06GEOGRAPHY/GEOLOGY
page.content: There are three main rock types in the Addington area, Chalk (porous) Blackheath Beds (pervious) and Thanet Sands (impermeable). All three rock types are sedimentary and the region has been gently folded. Because of the variety of rocks, Addington spring is found at Spout Hill where the Blackheath Beds and Thanet Sands meet. The spring provided water for the village although today it is not used. Quarrying existed during the last century. Both chalk and gravel pits were excavated. There are no quarries mined today, they are used as bunkers on the local golf course. The land use has changed during the last century, large housing estates have replaced arable farmland. There are no industries in Addington except for farming. Arable farming, pasture and market gardening are dominant.
